awd_abstract_narration:
Atomic clocks are the most accurate devices ever made by mankind, and they have many important technological applications. This project aims to significantly improve the precision of atomic clocks and other quantum devices such as atom interferometers. It will promote the progress of science by advancing the understanding of quantum mechanics and its potential technological applications. In this project, research and educational goals will be united by training undergraduate and graduate students in atomic physics research methods.  This project will also help to increase the participation in physics; in particular, three students from underrepresented backgrounds in science will complete their Ph.D.s working on this project.

A major frontier of physics is the control of non-classical states of many-body systems. Such control will enable novel quantum devices, and improve atomic precision measurements beyond the standard quantum limit through entanglement. The present project focusses on using light to manipulate and entangle atomic systems consisting of thousands to millions of atoms. The major goals are to create quantum degenerate Bose and Fermi gases purely by optical cooling, to generate highly entangled states of many atoms using light, and to demonstrate atom interferometers operating well beyond the standard quantum limit, and close to the Heisenberg limit.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Atomic clocks are the most accurate devices ever made by mankind, and have many important technological applications. Atomic clocks are based on the concept of interference between two energy levels, where the energy difference between the two levels constitutes a frequency or time standard. When a clock or other quantum interferometer is operated with independent particles, the quantized nature of the readout of the interferometer constitutes a source of noise, the so-called projection noise. This results in a precision that improves as the square root of the particle number (Standard Quantum Limit). Entanglement can be used to overcome the Standard Quantum Limit, and achieve a precision that increases faster with atom number.

We have demonstrated the first entangled optical-transition clock that operates below the Standard Quantum Limit, i.e. with a precision that is better than what can be accomplished with independent (unentangled) atoms. This has been accomplished with ytterbium atoms that interact with light circulating inside an optical resonator. The entanglement (spin squeezing) is achieved by first generating spin squeezing between the magnetic sublevels of the electronic ground state, and then transferring the entanglement to the optical transition with a laser pulse with high fidelity. The demonstrated atomic clock outperforms a clock with independent atoms by 4dB.

In this program, we have also developed a new paradigm for metrology beyond the Standard Quantum Limit, namely, time-reversal based metrology. In that approach, we switch the sign of a many-body Hamiltonian induced by light in order to effectively achieve an evolution backward in time. This can be used to amplify a small signal above the quantum noise. With this approach we have demonstrated a system where 15 measurements with independent atoms can be replaced by a single measurement using the new paradigm.

Furthermore, by applying laser cooling enhanced by machine learning to trapped atoms, we have generated a Bose-Einstein condensate from a room-temperature gas in less than 600ms, which constitutes a record time. Such systems will be useful for applications in quantum metrology.

The accomplished results promote the understanding of quantum mechanics and its potential technological applications for quantum sensors. The work has united research and educational goals by training undergraduate and graduate students, and has increased the participation of underrepresented groups. Three underrepresented minority students have participated on this project working towards their PhD.
